alert.note: Alert for Worcester (Massachusetts) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 11 at 9:58PM EDT until September 12 at 2:40PM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton MA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Massachusetts...New Hampshire... North Nashua River At Fitchburg affecting Worcester County. Nashua River At East Pepperell affecting Middlesex, Hillsborough and Worcester Counties. For the North Nashua River...including Fitchburg...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...North Nashua River at Fitchburg. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Flooding of low lying areas along the river can be expected. Flooding encroaches on businesses near the junction of River and Depot streets in Fitchburg. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM EDT Monday the stage was missing. - Bankfull stage is 6.5 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this evening to 7.5 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow morning to 4.5 feet early Wednesday afternoon. It will rise to 5.0 feet early Thursday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 6.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.5 feet on 04/03/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. To escape rising water, take the shortest path to higher ground. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 1000 AM EDT.
